titleInfo.title: Creating a tradition of biomedical research: contributions to the history of the Rockefeller University.

mods.note: Copy 1 and Copy 2: Autographed by editor
mods.abstract: Stapleton, Darwin H. The Rockefeller (University) effect: a phenomenon in biomedical science; Hollingsworth, J. Rogers. Institutionalizing excellence in biomedical research: the case of the Rockefeller University; Hansen, Bert. New images of a new medicine: visual evidence for the widespread popularity of therapeutic discoveries in America after 1885; Amsterdamska, Olga. Research at the hospital of the Rockefeller Institute for Medical Research; Hirsch, Jules. Rufus Cole and the clinical approach; McKellar, Shelley. Innovation in modern surgery: Alexis Carrel and blood vessel repair; Landecker, Hannah. Building A new type of body in which to grow a cell"; tissue culture at the Rockefeller Institute, 1910-1914; Unti, Bernard. "The doctors are so sure that they only are right"; the Rockefeller Institute and the defeat of vivisection reform in New York, 1908-1914; Helvoort, Ton van. The start of a cancer research tradition: Peyton Rous, James Ewing and viruses as a cause of cancer; Hanson, Elizabeth. Women scientists at the Rockefeller Institute, 1901-1940; Takahashi, Aya. Hideyo Noguchi, the pursuit of immunity and the persistence of fame: a reappraisal; Tierney, Abigail. Gasser, Bronk, and the international network of physiologists; Moburg, Carol L. James B. Murphy, the Rous sarcoma agent, and origins of modern cell biology; Olby, Robert. The Rockefeller University and the molecular revolution in biology; Brauckmann, Sabine. Paul A. Weiss, 1898-1989: the cell engineer."
mods.note: Copy 1; Copy 2; Copy 3; Copy 1 (610.7 ROC CHC)
